item.title: Emily Maitlis on Epstein, Prince Andrew, and why American journalists can’t do interviews
item.description: Emily Maitlis got one of the biggest scoops in the Jeffrey Epstein story when she interviewed Prince Andrew about his involvement in 2019.

item.title: Pablo Torre on ESPN, investigating LeBron, and becoming the New York Times’ first ‘creator’
item.description: Pablo Torre was one of ESPN’s rising stars — but now he’s building something outside the machine.

item.title: With new podcast, Blodget turns to ‘Solutions’ journalism
item.description: Henry Blodget talks to Semafor about getting back to the basics: writing and talking about what excites him in business and tech.

item.title: Amazon mulls Farrow two-for-one podcast deal
item.description: Ronan Farrow pitched a podcast co-hosted with his mother, actor Mia Farrow.

item.title: What happened to China’s US influencer program?
item.description: Nearly one month later, there’s no evidence the program happened as scheduled.

item.title: Israeli strike kills Al Jazeera journalists in Gaza
item.description: Israel had accused one of the journalists of being a Hamas fighter posing as a reporter.

item.title: The left gets a new publication
item.description: The Argument aims to articulate what the left is for, not just against.

item.title: YouTube’s Channel 5 vs. The New York Times
item.description: Andrew Callaghan’s Hunter Biden interview has gotten a lot of attention.

item.title: Vanity Fair’s new cruise director will have to choose between his reporters and his friends
item.description: Mark Guiducci has charisma, youth — and far less editorial experience than his recent predecessors.

item.title: Chips on the table
item.description: In big American media, the currencies most journalists trade in have been access and information, not cash.

item.title: FCC Chair Carr takes his Comcast fight to the ballpark
item.description: Brendan Carr backed the Yankees’ YES Network in its carriage dispute with Comcast, and threw the first pitch at Yankee Stadium as the standoff deepens.

item.title: New York Times teams up with Economist in play for worldwide readers
item.description: The US paper quietly rolled out the bundled subscription with the UK-based finance and business-focused publication earlier this year.

item.title: How AI will upend the news
item.description: Generative AI promises to revolutionize people’s relationship with information — and news organizations need to get ahead of that change.

item.title: Can investors make The New York Times into the Netflix of news?
item.description: Fivespan Partners has taken a stake in the Grey Lady.

item.title: Mehdi Hasan’s Zeteo wants to take on Politico Playbook from the left
item.description: The publication is expanding its politics coverage to gear up for the midterm elections.

item.title: Times reporter launches longform journalism project
item.description: The former New York Times media reporter Ravi Somaiya is launching Bungalow.

item.title: Inside the Boston Globe’s high-stakes investigation of the Boston Globe
item.description: The paper stood by one of its star editors after staffers accused him of berating them.

item.title: Can Bari Weiss remake one of the oldest US news channels?
item.description: The new owners of Paramount appear to think The Free Press founder can do it.
